_header: Problems of old likeness and figures
Subjects: birds, as narrators; fabliaux; advice, moral; envoys
_description: John Lydgate, ‘The Chorle and the Birde’ — fifty-four stanzas rhyme royal including 2-stanza envoy, plus one 8-line ‘Verba translatoris’ (ababbcbc)

OxfBal354.First Lines:
Problemes of olde lyknes & fygvresWhich preved ben fructuovs of
                    sentence…
OxfBal354.Last Lines:
…All thyynges ys sayd vnder correccounWith supportacion of hys
                    benyngnyte
OxfBal354.Note:
Probably a transcript of 
            Lydgate, John, [The chorle and the birde], [Westminster: W. Caxton, 1477?] ; missing stanzas 49 and
                    50.
OxfBal354.Attributed Title:
Þe chorle & þe byrde (p. 353); Here endith þe chorle
                    & the byrde (p. 360)
OxfBal354.Facsimiles:
Early Manuscripts at Oxford University: Facsimile
                    of Oxford, Balliol MS 354.
         (http://image.ox.ac.uk/show?collection=balliol&manuscript=ms354).

OxfChrCh152.First Lines:
Lerne the secound groundyd vpon scripturedesyre þou neuyr in
                    no condicoun…
OxfChrCh152.Last Lines:
…For alle ys seyde vndyr correccounWith supportacoun of your
                    benygnyte
OxfChrCh152.Note:
Missing lines 274-34; f. 274 misbound, should follow f.
                    277.
OxfChrCh152.Attributed Title: Here endyth the tale of the Churle and hys bryd (at the end)

CULHh412.First Lines:
Problemys liknes and signesWhiche proued ben fructuose of
                    sentence…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
…all thyng is said vndyr correccionWith supportacion of
                    ȝowre benignite

CULKk16.First Lines:
Problemus lykenessus & ffygurysWhiche prued byn ffructuous of
                    sentensse…
CULKk16.Last Lines:
…In other tymes sche hath no ffantesyThus euery thyng as
                    Clerkes spesyfye…

CamTCC599.First Lines:
[P]roblems of olde lykenes & figuresWhyche are prouyd fructuos
                    of sentenceAnd haue auctoryte groundyd in scriptureBy resemblance of
                    notable apparence…
CamTCC599.Last Lines:
…All þyng ys seyde vnder correccionWith supportacion of
                    your benygnyte
CamTCC599.Attributed Title:
The tale of þe byrde and the Chorle of thre notable & gret wysdoms
                    groundyd vppon these ii verses folowyng that ys to wete Ne nimis omissa
                        doleas nec omne quod audis Credas nec optas is quod habere nequis (f.
                        9ra)
CamTCC599.Facsimiles:
Fletcher,  Bradford Y. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Trinity R.3.19. A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, 1987.

BlCottCalAII.First Lines:
PRoblemys of old lyknesse & fyguresWhyche preuyd ben fructuous
                    of sentense…
BlCottCalAII.Last Lines:
…All thyng ys seyd vndyr correccion With supportacion of yowr
                    benygnite
BlCottCalAII.Note:
Transcript by Bp. Percy, London,  British Library Addit. 39547, f. 90.
                    ‘Explicit’ in lower margin f. 22, by scribe.
BlCottCalAII.Attributed Title:
The Chorle (by scribe as RT, verso leaves); The chorle & þe Byrd
                    printed (added by later hand to upper margin, f. 17); Another old poeme intitled
                    the Chorle (f. 1, sixteenth-century list of contents)

BLHar116.First Lines:
PRoblemys of olde liknese and figuresWhich proued been fructuous of
                    sentence…
BLHar116.Last Lines:
…Al thing is saide vndir correctiounWith supportacion of your
                    benignite
BLHar116.Editions:
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             A Selection from the Minor Poems of Don John Lydgate.
Percy Society
         2. London: T. Richard, 1840: 179-93.
Neilson,  William Allan,  and  Kenneth Grant Tremaye Webster.  
             Chief British Poets of the 14th and 15th Centuries
         London: Dent; and New York: Dutton, 1916: 208-13.
Tyroller,  Franz. 
             “Die Fabel von dem Mann und dem Vogel in ihrer Verbreitung in der
                Weltliterature.” 
             Litterarhistorische Forschungen
         51 (Berlin, 1912): 176.

BLHar2407.First Lines: Poyetys write wondurful lyknesand covert kepe hem selfe ful clos…
BLHar2407.Last Lines: …all thyng ys sayde vnder correcciounwith supportacioun of yowre benyngnite
BLHar2407.Note: 66 stanzas. Includes envoy; incomplete pen drawings (five on ff. 76-78) to illustrate, spaces left for further drawings throughout to f. 90.
BLHar2407.Editions:
Bowers,  Robert Hood. 
             “Lydgate’s ‘The Churl and the Bird’ MS Harley 2407 and
                Elias Ashmole.” 
             Modern Language Notes
         49 (1934): 90-94: 91-3 (8 stanzas only).

BLLan699.First Lines:
PRoblemys liknessis & ffiguresWhich previd been fructuous of
                    sentence…
BLLan699.Last Lines:
…All thyng is seide vndir correccionWith supportation of your
                    benygnyte
BLLan699.Note: Folio number reflects the most recent foliation.
BLLan699.Attributed Title:
Incipit de Aue & Rustico (f. 27v); Explicit Fabula
                        de Ave & Rustico (f. 34v)

MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS

Lincoln129.First Lines:
…Mid the gardyn stood a fressh laurertheron a brid syngyng
                    bothe day & nyhtwith sonnyssh fethers brihter than gold werwhich
                    with hir song makith heuy hertis liht…
Lincoln129.Last Lines:
…all thyng is seyd vndir correcciounwith supportacioun of your
                    benygnyte
Lincoln129.Attributed Author: Auth Joan. Lydgate (added by later hand, f. 74v)
Lincoln129.Editions:
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 468-85.

Longleat258.First Lines:
[P]roblemes of olde likenes and figuresWhiche proued ben ful
                    fructuous of sentence…
Longleat258.Last Lines:
…Alle thing is saide vndre correciounWith supportacion of his
                    benyngnyte
Longleat258.Attributed Title: Here endith the / Chorle and þe bridde (f. 147)
Longleat258.Editions:
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             English Verse between Chaucer and Surrey.
         Durham, NC: Duke UP, 1927: 104-10.

Austin143.First Lines:
Nobleness of olde likenes and figuresWhich provid ben fructuous of
                    sentens…
Austin143.Last Lines:
…And remembre you where that euere ne goneThat a Churlis Cheke
                    [sic] is allway wo begone…
Austin143.Note:
Ends imperfectly due to loss of leaves at l. 371; catchwords for
                    following line: ‘vnto the purpos’.
Austin143.Editions:
Lovell,  Robert Earl,
                        ed.  
             “John Lydgate’s Siege of Thebes and Churl and Bird:
                Edited from the Cardigan-Brudenell Manuscript.” 
         Diss. University of Texas at Austin, 1969: 215-34.

BosPLMed92.First Lines:
…Sumtyme þer was In a smal villargeAs myn Auctour maketh
                    rehersayleA chorle which had lust & gret corageWith In hym self by
                    dilligent trauayle…
BosPLMed92.Last Lines:
…haue ofte sythe grete sorow & myschauncewho þat hath
                    fredom he hath suffisaunceBetter is fredom with lytel in
                    gladnesseÞan to be thrall with all wordely rychesse
BosPLMed92.Note:
48 stanzas rhyme royal; missing stanzas 1-6; MS written in Calais
                        c. 1470 by scribe, V.C. Moris and another hand; owned by
                    ‘William Caston’ and given by him to ‘William Sonnyng’
                    in 1471; coat of arms of Thomas Wall on f. 1.

HunHM144.First Lines:
PRoblemys of olde likenesses and figuresWhiche prouyd been
                    fructuose of sentence…
HunHM144.Last Lines:
…All thyng is sayde vnder correcciounWith supportacion of your
                    benynghnyte
HunHM144.Attributed Title:
Here begynnyth the Tale of the Chorle and the Byrde (f. 135v);
                    Cherle & Byrde (RT)
